issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: A patch for this issue has been uploaded to JIRA by a contributor.
status.name: Patch Available

fields.description:
Got the following exception when running Hadoop on Power PC. The implementation for computing checksum when the data buffer and checksum buffer are not backed by arrays.

13/09/16 04:06:57 ERROR security.UserGroupInformation: PriviledgedActionException as:biadmin (auth:SIMPLE) cause:org.apache.hadoop.ipc.RemoteException(java.io.IOException): org.apache.hadoop.fs.ChecksumException: Checksum error
fields.summary: DataChecksum#calculateChunkedSums not working for PPC when buffers not backed by array

comments.body: Attached patch introduced a JNI method being used by DataChecksum when running on Power PC. Also, variable buf is always converted to little endian in method crc32c_sb8 in bulk_crc32.c

Just hitted the same issue with ibm jdk.
Your patch seem to work ! Many thanks !

I was testing with pi / teragen on a single node cluster, hitting a checksum error at the launch of the job.
Now it runs fine.
This patch resolves so many testcase errors and failures in PPC. This patch needs to be included in the upcoming release.

This patch resolves checksum errors in the existing tests. So no new tests are needed for this patch.

Native code tends to get neglected as too few of us are up to date with any more. I'm correct in assuming that the {{htoleXX()}} operations are just no-op macros on x86? So do nothing whatsoever to the existing x86 code path?

-1

Looking at [http://code.metager.de/source/xref/gnu/glibc/bits/byteswap.h] to answer my own question.

with the transform defined in the hadoop code, {{htole32()}} is doing something on all platforms.

{code}
#define htole32(x)      (bswap_32(htonl(x)))
{code}

Yet I don't see it being needed on x86: after all, it's not there until then. So the patch is adding a fair amount of needless byteswapping.

The transform should go away entirely on a little endian part, with something like:

{code}
#if defined __LITTLE_ENDIAN
#  define htole32(x) (x)
#else
#  define htole32(x) (bswap_32(htonl(x)))
#endif
{code}
also, {{byteswap.h}} isn't on windows ... which doesn't matter as it can use the no-op feature. the #ifdef logic is going to have to only include the file if it exists.

Hi Steve,

   I agree with your comments. Modified the patch like you mentioned above.

Hi Steve,
       I attached a new patch which deals with the windows env ( which is always Little Endian or atleast now )

Hi Ayappan, thanks for the patch, when validating on macosx, got compile error like:

{code}
     [exec] Building C object CMakeFiles/hadoop.dir/main/native/src/org/apache/hadoop/util/bulk_crc32.c.o
     [exec] /usr/bin/cc  -Dhadoop_EXPORTS -g -/Volumes/SSD/projects/hadoop-trunk/hadoop-common-project/hadoop-common/src/main/native/src/org/apache/hadoop/util/bulk_crc32.c:3Wall -O2 -D_REENTRANT -D_GNU_SOURCE -D_LARGEFILE_SOURCE -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64 -isysroot /Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Develo4:10: fatal error: 'byteswap.h' file not found
     [exec] #include <byteswap.h>
     [exec]          ^
     [exec] 1 error generated.
     [exec] make[2]: *** [CMakeFiles/hadoop.dir/main/native/src/org/apache/hadoop/util/bulk_crc32.c.o] Error 1
     [exec] make[1]: *** [CMakeFiles/hadoop.dir/all] Error 2
     [exec] make: *** [all] Error 2
{code}

I think a more standard way of handling byteorder stuff is needed(not only in this jira), like google did in many open sourced code bases:

https://github.com/google/flatbuffers/blob/master/include/flatbuffers/flatbuffers.h
A new jira ( HADOOP-11665 ) has been opened to fix this issue in a more standard way.
Not down as a blocker for 2.7
Not a blocker but it will be good if HADOOP-11665 make it to the 2.7 release. Thank You
